Award.AwardTitle: Study of Electrons in Superfluid Helium
Award.AbstractNarration:
****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****

Bubbles form in liquid as a result of a number of different processes. They can be produced when the pressure on a liquid that contains gas is reduced, when a can of Coca Cola is opened, for example. Bubbles also form in the turbulence around the propeller of a ship or when a liquid is heated above its boiling point. In some situations, bubble production has undesirable effects. For example, over the course of time the bubbles produced near the propeller of a ship, damage the propeller. On the other hand, bubble generation can also be very useful, as in an ultrasonic cleaner. The long-range goal of this research is the study of how bubbles are formed and how to control the formation for technological advantage. Experiments will be performed to investigate bubble production in liquid helium under a number of different conditions. Liquid helium is chosen for these experiments because it can be produced with exceptional purity, and so effects that might arise from impurities in the liquid can be controlled or eliminated. The research project will contribute to the national need for scientists trained in the technically important fields of optics, cryogenics, fluid mechanics and computer simulation.


****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****

An electron injected into liquid helium forces open a small cavity, producing an "electron bubble" of radius 2 nm. This individual investigator award supports research that includes several projects to study these bubbles and to use them to investigate the properties of quantized vortices. The first project will be to investigate the "exotic ions", electron bubbles of unknown structure that are smaller than normal bubbles. In a second project a study will be made of electron bubbles in which the electron has been optically excited to the 1D quantum state. The third project is to attach electron bubbles to quantized vortices and by imaging these electrons, study the motion of the vortices. This work is exciting because electron bubbles are unique quantum systems with a size and shape of the bubble determined by the quantum state of the electron. Their study can answer fundamental questions concerning the nature of the measurement process in quantum mechanics. The research is a combination of experiment and theory, and includes collaboration with groups in Paris and Barcelona. With the combination of these components, the research is an excellent means for the training of graduate students and undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research is focused on investigating the properties of helium at low temperatures. Helium is of great interest to scientists for two reasons. The first is that liquid helium has the unique property that it cannot be frozen simply by lowering the temperature. To make liquid helium freeze it is necessary to both lower the temperature and also apply a large pressure (360 pounds per square inch). The second interesting property is called superfluidity. Below a temperature of 2.17 degrees from absolute zero, the liquid has no viscosity. Helium can then flow through the smallest of channels. When an ordinary liquid is stirred, the motion of the liquid continues for a while but eventually the liquid will stop moving. However, once superfluid helium is set in motion it will continue to flow forever.  

We have performed experiments to study both solid and liquid helium. The work with solid helium was carried out as a collaboration with the group of  Sebastien Balibar at the Ecole Normale in Paris. Balibar’s group has developed a method to grow very perfect high-purity crystals of solid helium. These crystals were found to have remarkable elastic properties.  At the lowest temperature they were stiff but above a temperature of 0.1 K (0.1 degrees above absolute zero) they became soft  and their shape could be changed by a very small force. The reason for this peculiar behavior was investigated and it was shown to result from the motion of dislocations through the crystal. A dislocation is a line within the crystal along which the atoms are arranged in a way that is different from the periodic arrangement characteristic of ideal crystals.

In liquid helium we have studied the behavior of electrons immersed in the liquid. An electron is repelled by each  helium atom.  As a result if one electron is sent into the liquid it pushes the helium atoms away and becomes trapped in a small cavity referred to as an “electron bubble”. If a large number of electrons (e.g., one million) are sent into the liquid at the same time, these electrons sometimes become trapped in a single large bubble. We have studied these bubbles as part of a collaboration with the group of Ambarish Ghosh at the Indian Institute of Science in Bangalore. If just a few electrons are in a bubble, the bubble has an interesting shape because each electron repels every other electron. An example of the calculated shape of a bubble containing four electrons is shown in Fig. 1.

Calculations predict that a bubble containing a single electron should have a diameter of 4 nanometers; experimental results are in good agreement with this result. However, experiments have discovered that there are also other bubbles with negative charge which are smaller than this; these have become known as the “exotic ions”. At the moment it is not clear how this is possible. One intriguing possibility is that these bubbles each contain only a fraction of the wave function of an electron. Work is continuing to investigate this interesting possibility.

In our work we integrate the research with the education of the students who work on the project. The research involves the use of low-noise electronics, and acoustical, optical, and low temperature experimental techniques. It provides exceptional training for the students since these techniques are important in both industrial and university research. The students have benefitted from our collaborations with Paris, Bangalore and the group Manuel Barranco in Barcelona.  During the grant period three students completed their Ph.D. researchwork In addition, four undergraduates have worked in the lab.
